message_1:
A company collected data on their employees' salaries, education levels, years of experience, and job titles. The data was recorded in a 4x4 matrix A. Find the principal components of A and their corresponding eigenvalues. 

A = 
\begin{bmatrix} 
50000 & 2 & 5 & 3 \\
60000 & 4 & 10 & 7 \\
80000 & 6 & 15 & 12 \\
70000 & 8 & 20 & 18 \\
\end{bmatrix}
message_2:
To find the principal components of matrix A, we first need to standardize the data and then compute the covariance matrix. After that, we can find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix. The eigenvectors will be the principal components, and the eigenvalues will be their corresponding variances.

1. Standardize the data:

To standardize the data, we need to subtract the mean and divide by the standard deviation for each column.

Mean of each column:
mean_salaries = (50000 + 60000 + 80000 + 70000) / 4 = 65000
mean_education = (2 + 4 + 6 + 8) / 4 = 5
mean_experience = (5 + 10 + 15 + 20) / 4 = 12.5
mean_job_titles = (3 + 7 + 12 + 18) / 4 = 10

Standard deviation of each column:
std_salaries = sqrt(((50000-65000)^2 + (60000-65000)^2 + (80000-65000)^2 + (70000-65000)^2) / 4) ≈ 11180.34
std_education = sqrt(((2-5)^2 + (4-5)^2 + (6-5)^2 + (8-5)^2) / 4) ≈ 2.236
std_experience = sqrt(((5-12.5)^2 + (10-12.5)^2 + (15-12.5)^2 + (20-12.5)^2) / 4) ≈ 5.590
std_job_titles = sqrt(((3-10)^2 + (7-10)^2 + (12-10)^2 + (18-10)^2) / 4) ≈ 5.196

Standardized matrix A:
\begin{bmatrix} 
(50000-65000)/11180.34 & (2-5)/2.236 & (5-12.5)/5.590 & (3-10)/5.196 \\
(60000-65000)/11180.34 & (4-5)/2.236 & (10-12.5)/5.590 & (7-10)/5.196 \\
(80000-65000)/11180.34 & (6-5)/2.236 & (15-12.5)/5.590 & (12-10)/5.196 \\
(70000-65000)/11180.34 & (8-5)/2.236 & (20-12.5)/5.590 & (18-10)/5.196 \\
\end{bmatrix}

2. Compute the covariance matrix:

Covariance matrix C = (1/(n-1)) * (A^T * A), where n is the number of rows in A.

3. Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix:

Eigenvalues and eigenvectors can be found using various numerical methods, such as the power iteration method or QR algorithm.

The eigenvectors will be the principal components, and the eigenvalues will be their corresponding variances. Note that the principal components are orthogonal to each other, and they represent the directions of maximum variance in the data.
